body_html:
Just use get_tensor_by_name to get tensors from your graph. If you want add new operations to the graph, you can always mix existing tensors with the new ones.

i.e.

output_conv = vgg_graph.get_tensor_by_name('conv1_2:0')
some_new_node = tf.nn.conv2d(output_conv, W1, strides=[1, 1, 1, 1], padding='SAME') + b1 (w1,b1 are tf variables for weight and bias)
body_text:
Just use get_tensor_by_name to get tensors from your graph. If you want add new operations to the graph, you can always mix existing tensors with the new ones.
i.e.
output_conv = vgg_graph.get_tensor_by_name('conv1_2:0')
some_new_node = tf.nn.conv2d(output_conv, W1, strides=[1, 1, 1, 1], padding='SAME') + b1 (w1,b1 are tf variables for weight and bias)
body:
Just use **get_tensor_by_name** to get tensors from your graph. If you want add new operations to the graph, you can always mix existing tensors with the new ones.

i.e.
```
output_conv = vgg_graph.get_tensor_by_name('conv1_2:0')
some_new_node = tf.nn.conv2d(output_conv, W1, strides=[1, 1, 1, 1], padding='SAME') + b1 (w1,b1 are tf variables for weight and bias)

```
